area_name: West Nile Boulder (aka The Creek Boulder)

content.description: The hardest easiest looking line on the boulder (if that makes sense). A decent warmup.
content.protection: Weird uneven landing. Definitely pad it.
content.location: Left side of bloc. Start on obvious massive jug. Go straight up to big hueco sloper thingies.

climbs.name: Skin 'O My Teeth
climbs.fa: Maybe Andy Patterson. Then again, maybe not. Kinda an eliminate anyway.

content.description: Sort of the younger, less attractive but sporty brother of Countdown To Extinction. Start sitting at the jug of The Warmup, climb right into a fun crux that can be done a number of ways, and finish by topping out Le Privett. Pumpier than it looks.
content.location: Start on the left side of the boulder, on the obvious massive jug.

content.description: Start up the left arête of the bridge using only the arch stones for holds.  Head up and right, campus through crimps and hand bumps/matches, hit the crimp on the center keystone under the nipple, then lunge up right for the juggy hole and top out from there.
content.location: At the start of Rattlesnake Trail, look at the rock bridge made in 1919 where Las Canoas Road goes over the creek. S. H. Stonewall is on the North side, starting on the left arête and following only the lowest rocks that makeup the arch.

content.description: Multiple crazy hand-positions and the repeated use of a single undercling make this problem a gem. Dean Privett, the head-setter at Santa Barbara Rock Gym, loves underclings (and I do mean loves), so I coined this problem after him.
content.location: Begins on the right face of the boulder. Sit-start with left hand on good jug/crimp, and right hand on small vertical crimp. Fire up right to the big sloper/pinch, then head straight up via tricky feet, lots of re-positioning, and some trickery.

content.description: Start low on jug (same as warmup V3) hit left crimp and throw big to right edge and finish as for Le Bernd.

Stand start the prow of the boulder just right of The Warmup. Begin with left hand on sloper, and right hand on edge. Some surprisingly tricky footwork gains the top. Awesome line, and the easiest hard looking line on the boulder. Seriouslyjust looking at this thing we thought it was like V8.
content.protection: One pad will do it. Pretty flat landing.
content.location: Just right of The Warmup. Climbs prow overhanging the creek.

content.description: This boulder is a link up between the start of Skin O' My Teeth V9 and the crux of Countdown to Extinction V10. A bit contrived, but a fun recycle move on some small sandstone holds brings you to the perfect compression section of Countdown, one of the best cruxes I've ever climbed. The goal of this line is to capture the some of the best movement on the boulder. Minus stars for it being a contrived link up, but plus stars for not having a rock at the start like Countdown.
content.location: This route climbs the prow facing the creek. Low start on the huge jug on the left side of the prow. Traverse right through the small holds then bust straight up to a good edge/gaston that faces the wrong way. Finish straight up from here, through the crux of Countdown and into Le Bernd. If you go straight up by means of a left hand side pull above the start jug rather than traversing right, you're climbing Le Bernd Sit V5/6.

content.description: Complete awesome. Sit-start as for Le Privett, move left via a hard feet-cutting move, perform a ridiculous single hand movement, and finish on Le Bernd. Very, very hard. Named after the illustrious album by Megadeth.
content.location: Starts on Le Privett, finishes on Le Bernd.

pathTokens: West Nile Boulder (aka The Creek Boulder)
